text.headline: Indigenous Farmers vs. Juan Antonio Covarrubias
text.text:
Indigenous farmers used this manuscript map in a legal case to protect their lands from a Spanish sheep rancher.

Map of lands in the Tultepec and Jaltocán regions adjacent to the Hacienda de Santa Ines (Mexico)
Mexico, 1569 
Edward E. Ayer Collection

text.headline: Protecting Indigenous food supplies
text.text:
This horned ram represents the 5,000 to 20,000 sheep from the ranch of the Spaniard Juan Antonio Covarrubias that had intruded onto Indigenous farmers’ fields and were eating their crops. Beneath the ram is a handwritten note that demarcates the green area as “es de los yndios,” meaning it belongs to the Tultepec farmers. The crops were both a source of food for Indigenous farmers and a means of paying taxes to the Spanish, as outlined in this document. 

Philip II, King of Spain (1556-1598)
Royal cédula Madrid, to the Real Audiencia of New Spain in Mexico City, concerning the corn paid by the Indians as taxes, 1576 June 4
Madrid and Mexico City, 1576-1577
Edward E. Ayer Collection

text.headline: Uncovering symbols
text.text:
This map uses five small drawings of churches to represent five neighboring towns. Each church has an arched door and steeped roof, which contrast with the pier and lintel door frames seen on the Native houses dotting the central portion of the map. The difference in architecture styles reflects the cultural divide between Indigenous farmers and Spanish colonizers.

Detail from Map of lands in the Tultepec and Jaltocán regions adjacent to the Hacienda de Santa Ines (Mexico)
Mexico, 1569 
Edward E. Ayer Collection

text.headline: Indigenous MAP-making
text.text:
This map communicates the mapmaker’s ancestral ties through the use of amatl paper, which was being produced in Mexico well before the Spanish occupation. To make amatl paper, the thin, flaky bark of fig and mulberry trees is harvested and boiled down. The resulting viscous fibers are then laid in alternating layers to provide the paper with structure, then pounded flat into sheets.

Detail of amatl paper
Map of unidentified place, probably in central Mexico
Mexico(?), 1500s(?)
